Nitrogen oxides (NOx) emissions pose a threat to environment and human health. Based on that, selective catalytic reduction (SCR) with hydrogen has emerged as a promising strategy. Within this work, it has been developed a non-noble metal catalyst CuO-Fe2O3/TiO2, being compared with the monometallic corresponding cases, which exhibited outstanding performance in SCR of NOx with H2. CuO-Fe2O3/TiO2 catalyst achieved a NO conversion rate of 100 % at 300 °C, with high N2 selectivities (> 95 %), while NH3 was only formed at temperatures higher than 300 °C. Spectroscopic analysis and density functional theory calculations revealed the strong Cu-Fe interaction, promoting the formation and stabilization of Cu+ and Fe3+, while active sites increased, enhancing the whole catalytic activity. Finally, an economic analysis and life cycle evaluation positively supported the chemical results. Thus, this study demonstrates the potential of hydrogen-based SCR for industrial applications, when specifically using CuO-Fe2O3/TiO2. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Nitrogen oxide Selective catalytic reduction NO removal Synthesized ammonia 1 Introduction Nitric oxide (NO) is a major atmospheric pollutant and high concentrations can harm human health, as well as the environment. Therefore, NO removal, using suitable purification equipment or control technologies, is essential to mitigate its threatening effects [1,2]. Within this context, in the last years selective catalytic reduction (SCR) technology has been widely recognized as the most effective method for removing nitrogen oxides (NOx). SCR technology offers advantages such as efficiency, selectivity, reliability, flexibility, energy conservation and emission reduction. In fact, there are different reducing agents such as, ammonia (NH3), carbon monoxide (CO) and different hydrocarbons, which can effectively eliminate NO via SCR [3]. However, SCR may pose problems such as leakage of ammonia and generation of carbon dioxide (CO2). Thus, there is a need to explore new reducing agents. Hydrogen (H2) is widely used in various industrial production processes [4]. Using H2 as a reducing agent is an economical, non-toxic, pollution-free and effective strategy at low reaction temperatures [5,6]. With the advancement and increasing adoption of renewable energy sources, such as solar and wind power, hydrogen production and utilization have become increasingly accessible and sustainable [6,7]. Hence, the selection of H2 as a reducing agent has garnered substantial research attention [5,8,9]. For example, Xu et al. [10] synthesized a Pd/TiO2 NWs catalyst for H2-SCR, achieving a 62.6 % of conversion rate at around 200 °C and revealed that Pd–TiO2 interface enhances NO adsorption and activation. In a different work, Sei Moon et al. [11] developed a range of Pd/ZSM-5 catalysts using various calcination temperatures for H2-SCR, achieving 96.7 % of NOx conversion rate and 96.8 % of N2 selectivity at 150 °C. This research work highlighted the importance of high Pd dispersion within Pd/ZSM-5, for optimizing catalytic activity. Additionally, Zhang et al. [12] produced PtIr/TiO2 catalysts through a hydrothermal process, maintaining NOx conversion rates > 85 % within the 125–200 °C temperature range. In this case, findings emphasized the synergistic interactions among Pt, Ir and Ti, that led to the formation of active Pt0 and Ir0 sites and enhanced catalytic reactivity. All previous works, presents interesting results, although all of them use noble-meal as part of the catalytic systems. However, the prohibitively high cost of these metals for large-scale industrial applications hinders their application. Consequently, there is an urgent need to shift towards non-noble metal catalysts, as a viable alternative to their precious metal counterparts. Within this context, the aim of the present work was related to the CuO-Fe2O3/TiO2 catalytic system, a non-noble metal composition, which was meticulously prepared, characterized, evaluated and compared to the corresponding monometallic systems (Fe2O3/TiO2 and CuO/TiO2). CuO-Fe2O3/TiO2 demonstrated an exceptional catalytic performance, at ≤ 300 °C the NO conversion rate reached 100 %, in which the N2 selectivity exceeded 95 %. Therefore, using two common and economic transition metals, instead of noble-metals, offers substantial economic advantages, enhancing industrial feasibility of H2-SCR technology. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation Three different catalysts, containing Cu and/or Fe oxides supported in TiO2, were prepared using a simple co-precipitation impregnation method, being CuO/TiO2, Fe2O3/TiO2 and CuO-Fe2O3/TiO2 catalysts with a total metal loading of 20 % (Cu:Fe molar ratio = 1:2, in the CuO-Fe2O3-TiO2 case). First, Cu and/or Fe nitrates (Sigma-Aldrich and AR,) were added to a beaker; subsequently, 100 mL of deionized water was added to form a solution. A specific amount of TiO2 (Macklin, 25 nm, 99.99 %) was then added, and the solution was stirred thoroughly. Then, as precipitant 50 mL of a NaOH (Sinopharm, AR and 99 %) and Na2CO3 (Sinopharm, AR and 99.8 %) solution were prepared with concentrations of 3 and 1 mol/L, respectively. These two precipitants were mixed and added dropwise to the salt solution to achieve a basic pH value. The mixture was then aged overnight with continuous stirring, filtered and washed until a neutral pH was obtained in washing solution. The resultant powders were placed in a glass dish, dried in an electric blast drying oven at 80 °C until all the water evaporated, ground and placed in a muffle furnace at 500 °C for 3 h. The resulting catalysts were was named as CuO-Fe2O3/TiO2, CuO/TiO2 and Fe2O3/TiO2. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The experiments were conducted using an X-ray diffractometer (Bruker D8 Advance) to characterize the composition and crystallinity of the catalysts. The test conditions were as follows: a cobalt target (λ = 0.154 mm), a scanning speed of 10°/min, a scanning range 2θ = 10°–90°, a current range of 10–60 mA, and a voltage range of 20–70 kV. Then, textural properties of all catalysts were determined using a N2 adsorption-desorption analyzer (Micromeritics ASAP 2460). Before testing, all the samples were degassed at 150 °C for 4 h. Subsequently, the samples were analyzed by passing N2 gas, in liquid nitrogen with a P/P0 range of 0.01–1.0. Complementarily, the morphology, microstructure, lattice and defects, as well as elemental mapping images of the catalysts were obtained using an FEI Tecnai G2 F30 electron microscope. Furthermore, samples were analyzed via X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Scientific Escalab 250Xi) using Al-Kα radiation (1486.6 eV). Finally, a Micromeritics AutoChem 2720 catalyst characterization system was used for a hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) analysis. The test conditions were as follows: the catalyst was heated from 25 to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min, and then, a 10 % H2–Ar mixture (45 mL/min) was introduced. 2.3 Catalytic tests The catalyst performance was evaluated by determining NO removal, as well as NH3 and N2 selectivity, using a continuous-flow fixed-bed reactor. The simulated flue gas comprised 350 and 2000 ppm of NO and H2, respectively, while N2 was flowed as the equilibrium gas (100 mL/min). Catalyst samples were placed in reaction tubes and preconditioned for 30 min in flowing simulated flue gas. Subsequently, the reaction performance was measured at different temperature intervals typically at 50 °C increments. The reactor outlet was connected to an FTIR spectrometer (IS10, Thermo) to determine NO, NO2, N2O and NH3 concentrations. NO conversion, NH3 and N2 selectivity were calculated using the following equations: (1) [ N O ] c o n v e r s i o n = [ N O ] i n − [ N O ] o u t [ N O ] i n × 100 (2) [ N H 3 ] selectivity = [ N H 3 ] o u t [ N O ] i n − [ N O ] o u t × 100 (3) [ N 2 ] s e l e c t i v i t y = ( 1 − [ N H 3 ] o u t + 2 [ N 2 O ] o u t + [ N O 2 ] o u t [ N O ] i n − [ N O ] o u t ) × 100 2.4 Reaction mechanism determination In situ infrared spectroscopy was conducted using a Nexus 670 (Thermo Nicolet) Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) instrument. The catalyst was heated in-situ at 773 K for 40 min with an O2/N2 flow rate of 10 %. Subsequently, the catalyst was cooled to the desired temperature to obtain a reference spectrum. Spectra were collected with a resolution of 4 cm−1 over 100 scans. They were obtained separately for Eq. (4), corresponding to NO adsorption in an atmosphere of 350 ppm NO, and for Eq. (5), corresponding to NO + H2 adsorption in an atmosphere of 350 ppm NO and 2000 ppm H2. For the calculations in this study, the quantum ATK code and a linear combination of atomic orbitals approach were adopted [13]. The total spin polarization energy was calculated within the generalized gradient approximation in the Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof representation. The catalyst surface was simulated using (4 × 3 × 2) TiO2 (1 1 0) supercells with Fe and Cu atoms (24 Ti, 4 Fe, 2 Cu, and 54 O atoms in total). The lattice parameters were a = 16.05 Å, b = 9.515 Å, and c = 20.35 Å. Total energy convergence was achieved using a Γ-centered k-point lattice in the Monkhorst–Pack format specifically set to (4 × 4 × 1) [14,15]. The top two trilayers and adsorbates were relaxed until the residual pressure applied on each ion was <0.02 eV/Å. All adsorption and reactions occurred on the exposed surface, and the transition metal dopants were adjusted by the z-direction dipole moment. The climbing image nudging elastic band method was used to locate the transition states (TSs) for all the elemental reactions studied [16,17]. The reaction energy (ΔE) and activation energy (E a) were calculated from the Born–Oppenheimer energy differences between the initial state (IS), TS, and the final state (FS) as follows: (4) Δ E = E F S − E I S , (5) E a = E T S − E I S , where EIS, ETS, and EFS represent the energies of the IS, TS, and FS, respectively. The adsorption energy (Eads) is calculated as follows: (6) E a d s = E t o t a l − E s u b s t r a t e − E a d s o r b a t e Here, Etotal, Esubstrate, and Eadsorbate represent the total energies of the system, substrate and adsorbate, respectively. By convention, the more stable the structure, the more negative the adsorption energy. The desorption energy is taken as the negative of the adsorption energy. 3 Results and discussion CuO/TiO2, Fe2O3/TiO2 and CuO-Fe2O3/TiO2 microstructural features were characterized via high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM), as they are illustrated in Fig. 1 . HR-TEM images revealed that all these samples exhibited a nanoparticle homogeneous morphology. Notably, Cu and Fe elements were evenly distributed across the surface of the TiO2 nanoparticles. For the CuO/TiO2, Fe2O3/TiO2 and CuO-Fe2O3/TiO2 catalysts, small agglomerates were observed on surfaces. Additionally, the HR-TEM images revealed distinct lattice spacings. For anatase TiO2, there were identified 0.328, 0.242, and 0.168 nm lattices, corresponding to (110), (004) and (200) crystal planes, respectively. For CuO, lattice spacings of 0.272 and 0.232 nm were associated with the (110) and (111) crystal planes for CuO/TiO2 and CuO-Fe2O3/TiO2 catalysts, respectively. The observed decrease in the lattice spacing of CuO in the CuO-Fe2O3/TiO2 bimetallic catalysts may be attributed to Cu-Fe interactions. Furthermore, the energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy mapping of the CuO-Fe2O3/TiO2 catalyst (Fig. 1 g) revealed that Cu, Fe, O, and Ti were uniformly distributed on the catalyst surface. The XRD patterns of CuO/TiO2, Fe2O3/TiO2 and CuO-Fe2O3/TiO2 catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 a. For the TiO2 support, the diffraction peaks observed at 25.1, 37.8, 48.047, 53.89 and 55.06° correspond to the (101), (004), (200) and (105) crystal planes of TiO2 anatase (PDF 21-1272). Additionally, the peaks observed at 27.4, 36.1 and 41.2° are associated with the (110), (101) and (111) crystal planes of TiO2 rutile (PDF 21-1276). For CuO/TiO2 and CuO-Fe2O3/TiO2 catalysts, the diffraction peaks observed at 32.5 and 38.7° are attributed to CuO (110) and (111) crystal planes (PDF 48-1548). Moreover, in Fe2O3/TiO2 and CuO-Fe2O3/TiO2 cases, diffraction peaks observed at 24.1, 33.0, 49.4 and 54.0° correspond to (012), (104), (024) and (116) crystal planes of Fe2O3 (PDF 33-0664). It is noteworthy that for CuO-Fe2O3/TiO2 catalysts, the intensity of CuO and Fe2O3 diffraction peaks are reduced, which may be due to the reduced content of these crystal phases [18]. As it is shown in Table 1 , CuO/TiO₂, Fe₂O₃/TiO₂ and CuO-Fe₂O₃/TiO₂ catalysts have surface areas of 37.2, 50.4, and 48.3 m²/g, pore sizes of 26.3, 35.1, and 23.4 nm, as well as pore volumes of 0.24, 0.44 and 0.28 cm³/g, respectively. Compared to the CuO/TiO₂ and Fe₂O₃/TiO₂ catalysts, CuO-Fe₂O₃/TiO₂ catalyst has an intermediate surface area and pore volume but the smallest pore size. This may be due to the interaction between CuO and Fe₂O₃ during their coexistence, which affects crystal growth and pore formation, thereby altering the pore structure and surface area of the catalyst [19–21]. The elemental valence distribution on the sample surfaces was analyzed via XPS (Fig. 2d–f), in which Gaussian functions were used to fit the data and determine the valence states of each elemental component, as outlined in Table 2 . Fig. 2d shows the Cu 2p spectrum, where two primary peaks are observed at 933.9 and 954.2 eV, corresponding to Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2, respectively. In particular, peaks observed at 933.1 and 952.7 eV are attributed to Cu+, while those observed at 934.5 and 954.5 eV correspond to Cu2+ [22,23]. Notably, distinct satellite peaks at 942.4 eV, characteristic of Cu2+, are observed for the copper-containing catalysts [24]. This result confirms that copper species, in CuO/TiO2 and CuO-Fe2O3/TiO2, exist predominantly as Cu2+. However, a fraction of Cu+ is also present. The Cu+ content increases in the following order: CuO/TiO2 > CuO-Fe2O3/TiO2. This variation in Cu+ content leads to more vacancies in CuO-Fe2O3/TiO2, primarily because of the higher concentration. This increased presence of Cu+ enhances the redox reaction Cu+ + Fe3+ → Cu2+ + Fe2+ [25]. The XPS spectrum of the Fe 2p peak is shown in Fig. 2e. The primary Fe 2p peaks, and one satellite, are located at 718.6 (the satellite front), 711.4 (Fe 2p3/2) and 725.5 eV (Fe 2p1/2), respectively [26]. Owing to the substantial overlapping of the oxidation components of Fe 2p3/2 over a broad range, a two-state fit was applied to these components to accurately quantify the oxidation states around 711 eV. This fitting indicated that Fe, in the catalyst, is predominantly in an oxidized state likely because of air oxidation during calcination. The Fe 2p3/2 components obtained from the fitting were primarily identified as Fe2+ and Fe3+. Additionally, peak area calculations revealed that the Fe3+ content in these catalysts followed the order of Fe2O3/TiO2 < CuO-Fe2O3/TiO2. A higher Fe3+ content enhances the catalytic activity of the catalyst, which particularly must promote NO adsorption. The XPS analysis of O 1s reveals spectra for the CuO/TiO2, Fe2O3/TiO2 and CuO-Fe2O3/TiO2 catalysts, with two discernible peaks indicating varying oxygen-containing groups in each sample (Fig. 2f). A high binding energy peak was depicted at approximately 531.5 eV, which corresponds to superficial the surface chemisorption of oxygens (OS). Conversely, a lower binding energy peak, at approximately 529.7 eV, is attributed to lattice oxygens (OL) [27]. Table 2 shows that OS contents exhibit the following trend: CuO/TiO2 < Fe2O3/TiO2 < CuO-Fe2O3/TiO2. This trend indicates that Cu and Fe presence enhances the quantity of OS [28]. This increase in OS implies a strong interaction between Cu and Fe metals within the catalyst, potentially influencing the catalytic activity, particularly in NO activation [29]. H2-TPR is a valuable tool for evaluating the reducibility of chemical substances. In this study, H2-TPR analyses were conducted for all the catalysts; the results are illustrated in Fig. 2b For the monometallic Fe2O3/TiO2 catalyst, a reduction peak was observed at 488 °C, which is attributed to the reduction of TiO2 to TiOx [30,31]. Conversely, the monometallic CuO/TiO2 catalyst exhibited a reduction peak at 152 °C, indicating the reduction of highly dispersed copper (Cu2+ → Cu+ → Cu0) [32,33]. In this second case, the TiO2 reduction was not detected, as titanium must be stabilized by the copper presence. Thus, in case of the CuO-Fe2O3/TiO2 bimetallic catalyst, a prominent reduction peak was observed at 200 °C accompanied by weaker peaks at 398 and 488 °C. The prominent peak, as in the previous material, corresponds to the copper reduction processes Cu2+ → Cu+ → Cu0, and the weaker peaks observed at 398 and 488 °C correspond to Fe2O3 → FeO, with TiO2 assisting in the reduction (Fe2O3 → FeO with TiO2 → TiOx) [30,31]. Importantly, it must be pointed out that incorporating bimetallic components into the catalyst led to a substantial increase in the areas of the Cu and Fe reduction peaks, indicating enhanced Cu–Fe interactions, consistent with the XRD and XPS characterization results. The NO temperature-programmed desorption (NO-TPD) results for the CuO/TiO2, Fe2O3/TiO2 and CuO-Fe2O3/TiO2 catalysts are depicted in Fig. 2c. An absorption peak was observed around 134 °C, corresponding to the desorption of NO2 [34], mostly depicted in the copper containing materials. Additionally, a prominent NO desorption peak was observed at around 327–340 °C, which can be attributed to the desorption of monodentate and bidentate nitrate species, and the decomposition of complexed nitrate [35,36]. Notably, CuO-Fe2O3/TiO2 catalyst desorption nitrates signal exhibited a broader peak, which in fact was slightly shifted to lower temperatures. These results indicate that CuO-Fe2O3/TiO2 catalysts offer ample adsorption sites for NOx, signifying potential advantage in NOx catalytic reactions, such as low temperature selective catalytic reduction. The catalytic activity for H2-SCR was assessed across a temperature range of 50–500 °C using a fixed-bed reaction setup, while product quantification was conducted via FTIR. Fig. 3 shows the NO conversion and byproduct concentrations. Fig. 3a shows the NO conversions obtained for the three different catalysts, as a function of temperature, where clear improving performance trends are depicted. Below 150 °C, all these catalysts exhibited negligible or low NO conversions, with minimal variation among them. However, the NOx conversion increased with increasing temperature for all catalysts, with the CuO-Fe2O3/TiO2 catalyst giving the best performance at the lowest temperature. At 200 °C, NO conversion exceeded 60 %, reaching 100 % at 300 °C, with N2 selectivity exceeding 95 % (Fig. 3c). These values were notably higher than those observed for the monometallic CuO/TiO2 and Fe2O3/TiO2 catalysts, which only reached 20 or 0 % of NO conversions at 200 °C, respectively. In fact, monometallic catalysts only reached total NO conversions at temperatures higher than 350 °C. This improvement can be attributed to the enhanced electron transfer facilitated by Cu–Fe interactions in the bimetallic catalyst. The presence of Cu enhances NO adsorption and activation, lowering the reaction temperature and enhancing catalytic efficiency. All these catalysts produced negligible amounts of byproducts, such as N2O and NO2 (Fig. 3d and e). Notably, compared to previously reported catalysts in Table 3 , the CuO-Fe2O3/TiO2 system demonstrates superior NO conversion efficiency and enhanced N2 selectivity [37–44]. Furthermore, this catalyst exhibits a significantly broader temperature activity range (200–500 °C vs. ≤ 300 °C for most benchmark systems). Notably, the CuO-Fe2O3/TiO2 catalyst transformed upon reaching 300 °C, producing NH3 and enabling the synthesis of NH3 from NO At 350 °C, NH3 selectivity exceeded 60 %, increasing to > 90 % at 450 °C. Fig. 3b shows that minimal NH3 generation occurred at low temperatures and that the H2-SCR reaction (2NO + 2H2 → N2 + 2H2O) primarily yielded N2. As the temperature increased, N* generated from the dissociation of NO adsorbed on the catalyst surface combines with H* to produce NH3 (2NO + 5H2 → 2NH3 + 2H2O). From 450 °C, a substantial amount of NH3 was produced when using the CuO-Fe2O3/TiO2 catalyst. Nevertheless, NH3 selectivity did not reach 50 % when using the monometallic materials. As temperature continued to increase, once sufficient NH3 was generated, NH3 and NO underwent NH3-SCR (6NO + 4NH3 → 5N2 + 6H2O). Thus, introducing a bimetallic catalyst reduced the temperature required for ammonia synthesis from NO and enhanced NH3 selectivity. This effect is attributed to the increased Cu+ and Fe3+ contents, which promote NO adsorption and activation, facilitating the overall reaction. Stability is a crucial parameter for evaluating catalyst performance. Therefore, CuO-Fe2O3/TiO2 catalytic stability, at 300 °C, is illustrated in Fig. 3f. This catalyst maintained a NO conversion rate of 100 % (GHSV = 41,000 h−1), during 48 h. There was neither a decrease in NO conversion, indicating that CuO-Fe2O3/TiO2 catalyst exhibits an excellent catalytic stability. In addition, these catalysts were tested for H2O and SO2 resistance, and as it is shown in the inset of Fig. 3f, with the introduction of 5 vol. % H2O and 100 ppm SO2 at 300 °C, the NO conversion rapidly dropped from 100 to 62 % within 15 min, and then rebounded to 70 % within 15 min, where it stayed constant. After removal of H2O+SO2, the NO conversion returned to 100 % within 30 min, a reversible deactivation. Complementing the catalytic analysis, in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) is an effective tool to explore the formation and evolution of adsorbed species on the catalyst surface, during the H2-SCR reaction over CuO-Fe2O3/TiO2 catalysts. Fig. 4 a depicts the in situ DRIFTS spectra for NO adsorption on CuO-Fe2O3/TiO2 catalyst. The vibration bands observed at 1245 and 1580 cm−1 correspond to bridged and bidentate nitrates, respectively. Additionally, the vibration band at 1604 cm−1 indicates adsorption of the bridging nitrate [45]. Furthermore, the signal depicted at 1282 cm−1 corresponds to N2O2 1- species, originated from the substantial reduction of nitrate or nitrite species, after NO adsorption by CuO-Fe2O3/TiO2 catalysts [46]. The bridging nitrate (1245 and 1604 cm−1) and bidentate nitrate (1580 cm−1) vibration bands gradually diminish inversely to temperature, disappearing once temperature exceeds 250 °C, indicating their involvement in reactions at lower temperatures [47,48]. After the NO adsorption analysis, NO and H2 gases were simultaneously introduced into the DRIFTS reaction cell, as the corresponding spectra are presented in Fig. 4b Spectral bands were observed at 3211 and 3125 cm−1, indicating the presence of –OH groups and the generation of H2O [15,49]. In this case, bridging nitrates (1604 and 1282 cm−1) were only detected on the catalyst surface at low temperatures. As the temperature increased, the bridging nitrates gradually disappeared, while NH3 (3356 and 1205 cm−1) coordinated to Lewis acidic sites emerged [50]. This result is in good agreement corroborating that NO reacts with H2 at high temperatures, to form NH3. In fact, the peaks of NH3 ligands vibration bands (3349 and 1190 cm−1) at Lewis acidic sites were gradually intensified with increasing temperatures, indicating larger NH3 productions. Through the above study, the reaction pathways of H2-SCR were explored, as it is illustrated in Fig. 4c. Among these pathways, rate-determining steps for paths 1 and 2 are *O + *NNO → *O + *O + *N2 and *N + *O + *N + *O → *O + *O + *N2. The energy barrier for the rate-determining step of path 1 is 3.18 eV, while that for path 2 is 3.54 eV. The lower energy barrier (3.18 eV) calculated for path 1 is more favorable than that for path 2, strongly suggesting that path 1 is likely the predominant reaction pathway for H2-SCR. The reaction pathways for the hydrogenation of NO to synthesize ammonia were also investigated, as shown in Fig. 4d Among three different pathways, the rate-determining step of path 1 is *NO + (H+ +e−) → *NOH, while those for paths 2 and 3 is *NO + (H+ +e−) → *NHO. Path 1 differs from path 2, because the initial hydrogenation reaction occurs at the O-atom or N-atom end of *NO. Paths 2 and 3 determine whether the second step of *NHOH hydrogenation adds to the N atom or the O atom of *HNOH. For paths 1 and 2, *NH2 + (H+ +e−) → *NH3 is the rate-limiting reaction step, with an energy barrier of 2.63 eV. Conversely, for path 3, *NH3 + *OH + (H+ +e−) → *NH3 + H2O is the rate-limiting step, and it requires a higher energy barrier (3.23 eV) compared with those of paths 1 and 2. The initial two steps of path 1 are spontaneous relative to path 2, indicating that path 1 is the most likely reaction pathway. Complementarily, it was conducted an economic feasibility analysis and life cycle evaluation of denitrification catalysts. The former analysis assesses investment costs, operating costs and benefits to determine the most cost-effective option. The annuity technoeconomic assessment method estimates costs [51]. Furthermore, the latter analysis comprehensively evaluates the environmental and social impacts of these catalysts across their entire life cycle, from production through use to disposal. By combining these methods, the economic, environmental and social benefits of the catalyst programs can be comprehensively assessed. This approach offers a scientific basis for decision-making and promotes sustainable development and green production. The system cost primarily comprises investment and operating costs. Investment costs cover equipment purchase, construction, contingency, etc., while operating costs include labor, maintenance, material and utility, as well as management costs. In this study, the cost analysis was conducted following a framework reported in literature [52]. The working capital was assumed to be 5 % of the capital [53]. The cost per ton of NOx treated with different reductants is shown in Fig. 5 a, indicating that treating NO with green hydrogen costs 333 ¥/t, which is substantially lower than the cost for other reducing agents, being approximately 15 % of the cost of NH3. Selecting hydrogen as the primary reducing agent facilitates industrialization. Furthermore, a life cycle assessment of the entire system was conducted using the ReCiPe Midpoint (H) analysis method to assess the whole life cycle for reducing 1 kg of NOx. The results revealed that green hydrogen, as a reducing agent, yields the lowest carbon emission value (GWP100) for the system at 0.18 kg per year (Fig. 5b). This contributes to mitigation of global warming and reduction of environmental impact. Low carbon emissions promote sustainable development and pave the way for a brighter future. 4 Conclusions In this study, a CuO-Fe2O3/TiO2 non-noble metal catalyst was successfully synthesized, using a straightforward co-precipitation method, achieving outstanding catalytic performances. The regulation of NO conversion to N2 or NH3 was controlled by manipulating the temperature—NO conversion reaching 100 % efficiencies, and N2 selectivity exceeded 95 % at 300 °C. Various analytical techniques were employed, including XRD, XPS and H2-TPR, to investigate the impact of introducing bimetallic catalysts. The CuO-Fe2O3/TiO2 catalysts notably enhanced the generation and stabilization of Cu+ and Fe3+, increasing the Cu reduction, while substantially inhibiting the Fe reduction. These findings firmly establish that the interaction between copper and iron bimetals enhances active site formation and catalytic activity. Furthermore, FTIR analysis and DFT calculations were used to elucidate the conversion mechanisms and plausible reaction pathways of NO, as well as its intermediates and adsorption species. This detailed analysis allowed to determine the reaction dynamics. Complementarily, economic feasibility analysis demonstrated that selecting H2 for NO treatment incurs substantially lower costs, compared with other reducing atmospheres (approximately 15 % of the cost of NH3) with minimal environmental impact. Thus, the present study shows promising potential to advance industrial H2-SCR technology and effectively integrate denitrification with NH3 synthesis. These advancements are pivotal for promoting sustainable and environmentally responsible industrial processes. coredata.dc:description: Nitrogen oxides (NOx) emissions pose a threat to environment and human health. Based on that, selective catalytic reduction (SCR) with hydrogen has emerged as a promising strategy. Within this work, it has been developed a non-noble metal catalyst CuO-Fe2O3/TiO2, being compared with the monometallic corresponding cases, which exhibited outstanding performance in SCR of NOx with H2. CuO-Fe2O3/TiO2 catalyst achieved a NO conversion rate of 100 % at 300 °C, with high N2 selectivities (> 95 %), while NH3 was only formed at temperatures higher than 300 °C. Spectroscopic analysis and density functional theory calculations revealed the strong Cu-Fe interaction, promoting the formation and stabilization of Cu+ and Fe3+, while active sites increased, enhancing the whole catalytic activity. Finally, an economic analysis and life cycle evaluation positively supported the chemical results. Thus, this study demonstrates the potential of hydrogen-based SCR for industrial applications, when specifically using CuO-Fe2O3/TiO2.
